raw_text:
Tory candidate quits over remark
 
 A Conservative election challenger is quitting after being quoted as wanting a "period of creative destruction in the public services".
 
 Danny Kruger, who also works in the Tory research unit, had been due to take on Tony Blair in Sedgefield. He says his remark last week was misrepresented but he will not contest the election for fear of damaging the Conservative cause. Tory leader Michael Howard accepted his decision "with regret". Mr Kruger was quoted in the Guardian newspaper saying: "We plan to introduce a period of creative destruction in the public services."
 
 In a statement, the party said the comment had been taken out of context. "He fully supports the party's policies on, and approach to, the public services," said the statement. "However, in order to avoid any further misrepresentation of his views and any damage to the Party, he has decided not to stand in the Sedgefield constituency at the next election." Mr Kruger is continuing in his job at the Tory campaign headquarters. Labour election coordinator Alan Milburn claimed Mr Kruger had exposed the Tory agenda for £35bn of cuts to public services. Mr Milburn said: "He is not some unknown hopeful fighting an unwinnable seat. He is a man who has worked at the heart of Conservative policy development... "His claim that the Tories were planning 'a period of creative destruction in the public services' is not a rogue claim. "It is the authentic and shocking voice of the Conservative Party. It reveals the true picture of what they would do."
llama3.2:1b: Tory candidate Danny Kruger quits election due to remarks made about his party's policies.
He was quoted as wanting "a period of creative destruction in the public services" but later says he will not contest due to fear of damaging Conservative cause.
Tory leader Michael Howard accepted decision with regret, while Labour claim he was misquoted and exposed the Tories' agenda for £35bn cuts to public services.
llama3.2:3b: A Conservative candidate, Danny Kruger, quit his election bid after being quoted as wanting to introduce "creative destruction" in public services, with the party accepting his decision with regret.
gemma2:2b: Danny Kruger, a Tory election challenger, withdrew his candidacy after being quoted as saying "we plan to introduce a period of creative destruction in public services".
The party denies misrepresenting his views, stating he supports their policies and will not stand in Sedgefield.
Labour claims the quote reveals a conservative plan for substantial cuts to public services.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Tory candidate Danny Kruger, who previously worked in the Tory research unit but left to contest the election due to potential damage to the cause, has quit citing a statement by his colleague that he had misrepresented a remark about creative destruction in public services.
He plans to continue working at the campaign headquarters after leaving office.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Danny Kruger, working for the Tory research unit, quit his bid to challenge Tony Blair over Sedgefield after being quoted as wanting a "period of creative destruction" in public services, saying it was taken out of context and damaging to the party.
qwen2.5:3b: A Tory candidate, Danny Kruger, has quit after being quoted as wanting a "period of creative destruction" in public services.
Despite Kruger saying his remark was misrepresented, he decided not to contest the election due to fear it might damage the Conservative cause.
The party clarified that this comment had been taken out context and confirmed that Kruger fully supports their policies on public services.

Labour election coordinator Alan Milburn claimed that Mr Kruger exposed the Tory agenda for £35bn of cuts to public services, describing Kruger as a key figure in policy development who accurately reflected the Conservative Party's stance.

His statement was misrepresented by the party but he is not contesting the election because it would damage the Conservative cause.
The Tory leader, Michael Howard, accepted his decision with regret.

Mr. Kruger, continuing in his job at the campaign headquarters, has claims that the Conservatives are planning a period of creative destruction, which he argues is authentic and shocking evidence against opposition.
Labour's election coordinator, Alan Milburn, mentioned his claims about public service cuts, labeling them as genuine support for the party.

Kruger had been due to take on Tony Blair in Sedgefield but decided not to contest the election citing his desire for "a period of creative destruction" in the public services.

The Conservatives have released a statement stating that Kruger fully supports their policies and approach, and is continuing in his job at Tories' campaign headquarters despite being criticized for his comments.
Labour's Alan Milburn claimed that Kruger exposed the party's agenda for £35bn of cuts to public services.
The allegation was not something the Conservatives would tolerate.

Danny Kruger, who works for Tory researchers, was quoted as saying that he wanted the UK to experience this type of change amid the Tories's campaign to cut public spending.
Mr. Kruger said his remark last week had been misrepresented, but expressed concern over how it could impact the Conservatives' chances in Sedgefield.
He will not contest the election for fear of damaging the party's image.
Mr. Howard, Tory leader Michael, accepted the decision "with regret," stating that the comment has been taken out of context.
In a statement, the party said the comment had been taken out of context and clarified that they are in favor of maintaining current policies on public services while making necessary changes.
